dc:description:
CRYM was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant nonsyndromic hearing loss in 2003 (Abe et al., PMID: 12471561). Three variants (stop loss, missense) that have been reported in three probands in two publications are included in this curation. These variants segregated with disease in 7 additional family members in two families (PMIDs: 12471561, 32742378).
The mechanism of pathogenicity is unknown. This gene-disease association is also supported by 
expression studies and in vitro functional assays (PMIDs: 16740909, 18448257, 24676347, 26915689). Of note, both homozygous and heterozygous CRYM null mice do not have hearing loss (PMID: 17264173). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease
relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing
evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the Hearing Loss GCEP on 2/16/2017. It was
reevaluated on 9/21/2021 (SOP v8). As a result of this reevaluation, the classification did not
change. Although new literature was published (PMID: 32742378), the scoring still corresponded to a limited gene-disease relationship.

evidence.dc:description: De novo variants are not additionally convincing or suspicious in the hearing loss field. Additionally, the GCEP felt that because this was a candidate gene analysis, the variant should be downgraded.

COS-7 cells were transfected with WT and variant HA-tagged CRYM constructs and subcellular localization was investigated. 24 h and 48 h after transfection both mutant and wt proteins displayed diffuse cytoplasmic staining. However at 72 and 96 h, both mutant CRYMs exhibited a vacuolation pattern in the case of the p.*315Y variant and stronger staining in perinuclear regions.
The hearing loss of this patient was not consistent with other patients with CRYM variants (it was not progressive). Therefore, we downgraded this variant.

COS-7 cells were transfected with WT and variant HA-tagged CRYM constructs and subcellular localization was investigated. 24 h and 48 h after transfection both mutant and wt proteins displayed diffuse cytoplasmic staining. However at 72 and 96 h, both mutant CRYMs exhibited a vacuolation pattern in the case of the p.*315Y variant and stronger staining in perinuclear regions in the p.K314T variant.

member.rdfs:label: Wang_Family Proband
member.phenotypeFreeText: sensorineural deafness in the right ear and a high‑frequency hearing loss in the left ear
member.previousTestingDescription: The Hereditary Hearing Loss Array Detection Kit was used to scan for variants in HL genes. A total of 15 mutations of four deafness‑associated genes were testable. None of these were present in this family.

evidence.dc:description: There are not enough affected segregations in this family to count it.
evidence.rdfs:label: Abe_Family 12

member.rdfs:label: Abe_Family 12 Proband
member.detectionMethod: All individuals were tested for variants in CRYM only based on its expression in inner ear in a microarray study.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Stable bilateral severe SNHL affecting all frequencies, onset around 1 year
member.previousTestingDescription: All individuals in this paper were previously tested and found negative for variants in GJB2 and mtRNR1

evidence.dc:description: This mouse did not have hearing loss.
These mice did not have hearing loss. However, both human variants are either a missense or a stop loss variant, so it's unclear if they would be causing a LOF.
evidence.rdfs:label: Suzuki_Mouse

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 points given because not clear how T3 binding is related to hearing loss, however cell lysates came from human blood cells. CRYM is known to be a carrier protein of T3, and T3 may regulate hearing, but still no direct link to HL. Two different mechanisms for hearing loss are proposed, given the truncation variant did not reduce T3 binding

Binding affinity constant between CRYM and T3 was assessed for WT and variant CRYM with the variants seen in Families 1 and 12. The p.K314T but not the p.*315Y variant significantly reduced binding affinity.
evidence.rdfs:label: CRYM and T3 binding affinity

evidence.dc:description: CRYM expression was detected in the marmoset. Expression was broader than in mice- was detected in both inner and outer hair cells and supporting cells. This suggests that mice may not be a good model for CRYM deafness.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hosoya_Expression

evidence.dc:description: 0.25 points given because these results are similar to other expression studies
Same findings as Abe and Oshima. Crym was found in type II fibrocytes in the mouse cochlea. In rats, it was also distributed in the stria vascularis
evidence.rdfs:label: Usami_Expression

evidence.dc:description: Mouse cochlea were immunostained for CRYM. Consistent with Abe 2003's findings, crym was detected in the type II fibrocytes of the spiral ligmanet, and not the spiral limbus, the stria vascularis, or spiral prominent. CRYM was also found to colocalize with ATPaseB1, known to also be regulated by T3
evidence.rdfs:label: Oshima_Expression

evidence.dc:description: 0.25 points given because no explanation of relevance to CRYM hearing loss is provided
Investigation of differential expression of many genes in the mouse cochlea between apical, middle, and basal turns revealed that CRYM expression was higher in the apex than in the base.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yoshimura_Expression

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization in mouse cochlea revealed CRYM expression in the fibrocytes of spiral ligaments and the spiral limbus. No CRYM was detected in inner or outer hair cells
evidence.rdfs:label: Abe_Expression
